First, let me break down each scenario. 

Scenario 1: The main character is too sleepy to drive safely and decides to buckle up their twins first. Wait, buckling up the twins first? That seems odd. Normally, you buckle up yourself before driving. But if they are too sleepy to drive safely, maybe they are trying to get the kids buckled up so they can drive? But if they are too sleepy to drive safely, then driving at all would be dangerous. But if they are driving while sleepy, then that's the issue. However, the scenario says "I'll buckle up my twins first." Maybe that's a way of saying they are preparing to drive, but if they are too sleepy, then driving is unsafe. So the main action here is driving while sleepy, which is morally wrong. Maybe the scenario is that they are too sleepy to drive safely, so they decide to let the twins buckle up first, implying that they are going to drive, but they are too sleepy. So the problem here is that driving while drowsy is dangerous. According to US standards, driving while drowsy is considered reckless and morally wrong. So Scenario 1 might be considered morally wrong.

Scenario 2: The main character omitted peanuts in his meal because he's allergic to them. So they didn't include peanuts in his meal to prevent an allergic reaction. That's a responsible action. If someone is allergic, omitting the allergen is the right thing to do. So this is not morally wrong. So Scenario 2 is not wrong.
